element_texts.text: Completed

in pencil in top margin   [no date]  Stoutemeyer, Vernon
I have no real estate in Illinois now - it was not very profitable so I liquidated it some time ago.  My father is still there however.

   I remember Fay Slobod well.  I suppose that she has a family of children by now.
   The oldest daughter is a junior in college - the oldest son - a freshman in Cal Tech at Pasadena.  How fast children grow up!
   I am still strong and can do a hard days work - but my hair is getting grayer.
  With my numerous moves - I have lost most of my book collection by the Wayside UTS
Completed

letterhead  VERNON T. STOUTEMYER  15250 Friends Street   Pacific Palisades, California
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 South Green St
Chicago - Illinois
Dear Jack-

    It was really a surprise to hear from you after all these years!  Many thanks for the book of humorous Americana.  I have read the first part of it and it brought back memories of some of the humorists I knew as an Illinois farm boy - Jack Billings, George Ade, Booth Tarkington - Aunt Samantha - Eugene Field and a poet whose poems two maiden aunts used to read to me - Ben King.  I thought him really quite funny.   The too in those days the old victor and Edison phonographs - rather primitive things usually had a good many examples of humorous monologs.
   I have written steadily - technical horticultural papers mostly - about a hundred.  My book writing ventures have not come to fruition.  I was teamed up with a man who died before we completed a McGraw Hill book.  I was invited to participate in posthumous publication by the literary executor of this man but the whole plan was changed and was not interested.  Also I had a very demanding job by that time.
   I was well on the way with another but with changing jobs - regular arrival of children - house buying and building - I
Completed

-2-
was delayed and several books appeared which scooped that field - so I gave that up.

    I am working now on a monograph which is on a rather abstruse field of plant science in which virtually no one is working since a Russian scientist died in 1939.  It will take maybe 10 years of experiments to complete it.  It would never sell very many copies but would be alone in its field probably for a long time.
    Professionally I have done fairly well perhaps - tho the load of administrative work has slowed down my research.
    I find California stimulating - the ideal climate for a brain worker.  However, I keep some midwestern roots.  I have a small farm in Central Illinois.  I like Iowa, Indiana, and Illinois in many ways.  You are wise to keep an Ozark hideout.  I agree with ? Frank Lloyd Wright that all cities are outmoded.  I don't believe in investing anything in city property - too expendable in the modern world!  I have a house here - so perhaps I am inconsistent!  Well - the Italians build houses right up the slopes of their volcanos.  I used to work with a Sicilian who wold tell of watching the streams of lava flow around their villages (and  sometimes over them.)
   We do indeed live in a dangerous world but when I travel around the California, Nevada and Arizona deserts I try to figure out ow the American pioneers ever got
Completed

VERNON T. STOUTEMYER   15250 Friend Street    Pacific Palisades, California
through some of those places, I think that we must develop a Spartan toughness it [sic] we are to stand up under the war of nerves ahead of us.  On the other hand perhaps there s a need for a bit of Epicureanism - the ability to grasp and enjoy some of the small pleasures of life - even under great difficulties.  

   Professional work - scientific work -  is exacting and it is difficult to read widely  - to go much to the theater - etc. so perhaps it resolves itself to the choice of the best.  I think that it is a mistake - a sad one - to let a career in science - or anything else crowd out all of the things which make for complete living.
   In a way, perhaps you have encountered the same problem in your literary work on the encyclopaedia, [sic] when probably your creative impulses are more along the line of belles lettres.
   Book publishing is a tough game - costs are so high.  In the technical field, it is difficult to keep under $10.  That was one reason I did not go on with my first project - I felt that the drastic trimming necessary to
Completed

4
meet the budget would have emasculated the book and make it competitive with some already in the field.

    I contributed a chapter to a book to appear in August. - I don't expect to participate in royalties.  In fact some of my colleagues waive royalties in order to get publication in the form they want.
    The serious type of paper books interest me.  We need them and have needed them for years.  The French had them - long long ago.  Our local town library here has a good, successful section devoted to them.  A locally invented quick binding is used to give greater wear.
    I was on a weekly trade journal in Chicago for a time in 1928.  I was getting to know some of the local literary and artistic personalities of the near north Side - interesting folks - tho perhaps tinged with a bit of bohemianism.  I suppose you have discovered a group of congenial crossed out:  fellows people and have some stimulation from the group.  I suppose that there is considerable creative activity there as always.
    It is indeed interesting to encounter some old acquaintances - tho by pen - once again.  It is truly a small world!

Sincerely -
V. T. Stoutemyer
Completed

VERNON T. STOUTEMYER   15250 Friend Street    Pacific Palisades, California
Jan 27, 1954
Dear Jack -

     Did you see this rather interesting book on Chicago literary and artistic life of the past few decades?
         Alson J. Smith
         Chicago's Left Bank
         Henry Regnery Company -
         Chicago . 1953. 
   I have dipped into your book of midwest humor repeatedly with much interest and amusement!

Sincerely -
V. T. Stoutemyer
Completed

letterhead  VERNON T. STOUTEMYER   15250 Friend Street    Pacific Palisades, California
May 24 - 1963
Dear Jack -

  Many thanks for "The Disinherited."  The Paperback Revolution has brought back many fine things into print and I am glad that this document of the 30's will have a chance again in happier times.
   As the son of a farmer, I saw the farm recession of the 20's which hit us hard as my father had speculated in real estate.  The 30's are a vivid memory - one I would like to forget.  I was luck [sic] - I ate adequately
Completed

and slept warm, but a number of romances passed by - and I was a late starter in my profession.  I have one child in high school yet.

   Altho I have written many professional papers, I have not written a book yet.  I have material collected for one and possibly two.  I did contribute one chapter to a technical book.  I have worked on several which for one reason or another were unpublished.
    My research is going well, and I enjoy the University.
    When I lived in Illinois and when I worked in Chicago, Midlothian was a lovely countryside - I think it had several large golf clubs.  I imagine with country life and the nearby city - one has the best of both worlds - or has suburbia engulfed you.  Again thanks - VTS
Completed

Fudge Fudge Call the Judge
To give me a penny
To buy some Fudge
How many Pennies
did He give me 
Ten, Twenty, etc.
(over)
Completed

IM a Little dutch girl
Dressed in Blue
These are the things that I ?
Salute to the Captain
Bow to the Queen
Turn My Back to wicked old ?
Completed

Rope Skipping
Postman Postman do your duty
Here comes ________ American Beuty [sic]
She can Wibble

 "     "    Wabble

She can even do the splits
How many splits can she do
Ten Twenty etc.
Completed

Fire Fire False alarm
underlined: girl fell in  underlined: boy's arms
How many kisses did she recieve [sic]
Completed

I see London
I see France
I see Somebody's underpants
They're not white
&  "       "   pink
But boy o boy
They sure do stink
variant
I see London
I see The Fair
I see sombody's [sic] underwear
etc.
Completed

Down in the Valley
Where the green grass grows
There stood Suzy 
As Sweet as a rose
Along came Joey
and kissed her on the cheek
How many kisses did she recieve [sic]
Ten Twenty
Completed

Cinderella dressed in Yellow
Went downtown to meet Her fellow
On Her way Her girdle busted 
How many people were disgusted
ten twenty

letterhead  WIN STRACKE    411 EUGENIE STREET   CHICAGO 14, ILLINOIS 
4-27-49
Dear Jack:

     I'm sorry about being late Saturday night.  As a Habitue of Sat Night Progressive Parties I Had never known entertainment to begin before eleven so I thought myself an eager beaver when I showed up at ten-fifteen.  Well it was a fine party anyway

Yours
Win
Completed

in pencil in top margin   Stracke, Win
letterhead  letterhead  MRS. WIN STRACKE    411 EUGENIE STREET   CHICAGO 14, ILLINOIS
April 29, 1958
Dear Jack,

    Here is that gem I told you about some time ago.  I found it in an old copy of the Manchester Guardian.  Surely it belongs alongside the best of Julia Moore.
    Win sends his best to you and Gladys as do I,

Sincerely,
Genevieve Stracke
Completed

letterhead  WIN STRACKE    411 EUGENIE STREET   CHICAGO 14, ILLINOIS 
Aug 18  '59
Dear Brother

   By this time you and Gladys have moved, no doubt, to a new vineyard.  I trust that you have drunk from the living waters of Midlothian and that you both have come up visibly refreshed.  Give Margaret Jean my Warm regards and tell her that sister Ruth Plunket will never replace her in my affections.  --  Prayer Hankerchief [sic] indeed!
    Studs, Gig and I were in you old neighborhood about two weeks ago and attended an inspiring service at the Stratford Revival Center.  Brother A. A. Allen was preaching the Word and Joy, shouting and dancing confounded the Devil aplenty.  I think with a little more work and prayer we could bring our two Jewish bretheren [sic] over the line.
Completed

letterhead  WIN STRACKE    411 EUGENIE STREET   CHICAGO 14, ILLINOIS 

   Just think of the stars we would have in our crowns if we could effect this conversion to the true faith.  Get busy with them Pamphlets Brother.
   I must confess a little disappointment in your concern for the four thousand books in your library.  don't you know there is only [underlined: One]] book, Brother.  It was good enough for Mother and It's good enough for me.  You must excuse me now for the sinners are gathering at the "Twin Anchors" across the way and I still have a few copies of "Rats in the Beer Vat"

Yours in the Service
Brother Win
Completed

June 8, '65
Dear Brother in Christ

    Yes, Brother Jack, for five weeks or more I was esconced [sic] in 15E at the Veterens [sic] Research Hospital.  Ostensibly I was there because of a depression but to you I confess that my real reason was to have an extended opportunity for meditation and prayer - may I be forgiven for this duplicity.
     I too shall be journeying to Europe Late in September as the guest of that great champion of human rights - Alderman Bauler.  In the company of the alderman, Ralph Newman and other stalwarts I shall try to bring the Light to the benighted Bachinalians  who will be visiting the Oktoberfest in the beer-washed precincts of Munich.  Pray for the success of our mission.
    While at the VA I was Joined by a good mutual friend Rube Dorinson.  We found much comfort in each others company and you may be sure that you were in our thoughts and our Prayers.  our only regret is that you have not ever been in the service of the ?oncular Sain? so that you can not Join in next years retreat.  My only hope is that in our perigrinations doing the Lords work, our Paths may soon cross

Yours in the Faith 
Win
Completed

THE BIGGEST LITTLE PARK IN THE WORLD
(CENTENNIAL PARK ON CHESTNUT STREET)
WORDS AND MUSIC by WIN STRACKE
Dedicated to the veterans of the centenial [sic] (the Civil War Round Table) who, while they spilled no blood in commemorating the events of a hundred years ago, did manage to spill and dribble Liberal Quantities of Scotch, bourbon, beer champagne and other potables in pursuing their valliant efforts.
W.S.
OCT 6, 1965                                        
There's room for both of us in Centennial Park Jack, if they bury us standing up.
Completed

Dec 17, 1966
Dear Po' old Jack

    Forgive this mannic [sic] pen -- it does not do Justice to the delicacy of my thoughts toward you.
    Your wonderful letter already has an honored place among my treasured conroy archives.  The news about your memoirs is great.  I hereby demand no less than a chapter! (now this pen works fine.)
  Know that I am still one of your ardent deciples [sic].  No less than two days ago I suggested you to Ralph Newman as editor for the revived "Illinois Intelligencer" -- circa 1815-1830, -- the official organ of the Sesquicentennial Commission.  Ralph liked your doing it but was unwilling to take the responsibility for your making the move.  You would have to live in Chicago.  Don't despair -- there will be other opportunitys [sic] for lucrative employment and old "Eagle Eye" Stracke is ever on the alert!
Completed

Yesterday at Ralphs request I wrote a long letter to Ralph outlining my suggestions for improving his friend, Lyndon Johnson's image.  (Horrid Word)   This was not a difficult task.  But among my suggestions was that we throw a Wing Ding at the White House of real traditional music and love.  And who, other than yourself, did I suggest to sustain the rightful place of the folk-tale in the Great Society.  No one indeed!  This may very well come off.  I'll keep you posted.

   I have already submitted a plan to the commission which has been very well received to set up as many as eight regional folk festivals throughout the Sesqu. year (Dec 1967--Dec 1968)  You could certainly be used in this Project as an auxilliary [sic] Performer.
   Your book is great!  I am reading it slowly.  since you are one of the few people I know who knows of the existence of Edward Coles of Albemarle, you will be pleased to know that
Completed

Norman Luboff, Marv David and I have been commissioned by the commission to write a Dramatic - Musical Cantata about Gov. Coles and the anti-slavery struggle in early Illinois  1819 - 1824.  The working title, "Exodus underlined: to Egypt." (The idea and research are mine.)  We're all very much excited about it.

   I've been asked, tentatively, to play Bet & Million Gates for some underlined:  Steal companys [sic] during three week ends in April next which underlined: may interfere with our Arkansas plans.  But I'll get to see you somehow.
  Give my very best to Gladys.  And to you, old and dear friend,

deep Affectionate Greetings
Win
underlined:  Merry Christmas
Completed

Chicago Nov. 2, 1967
℅ Old Town School of Folk Music
333 W. North Ave, Chicago 60610
Dear Jack

     First let me apologize for not showing  up at your luncheon last spring.  I wan't showing up anywhere at the time -- in fact I was out of circulation for three months but, what the Hell here I am again half full of Piss and Vinegar.
    Dan Russell asks about you as does Bill Wedlake, Paul Romaine, Studs, Dawn Greening and others in which I join.  How are you?
    I took dinner with the Terkels last evening and they are their usual selves -- Ida still mounting the barricades in Peace Vigils and demonstrations (she was at the Pentagon of course), and Studs his usual ebullient self.  Studs' play re-written for the umpteenth time will be presented by the University of Michigan Drama Dept. next month.  With the success of "Division Street USA" he is much sought after and seems to be thriving on  it.  WFMT has been bought by -- hold your breath -- WGN Inc. but everyone is assured by the new management that there will be no change in policy, Honest injun!
   Norm Luboff and I finally finished our cantata "Freedom Country" about Gov. Edward Coles and the anti-slavery struggle in early Illinois 1823-24, and it is now at the printers.  It will be performed many times during the Illinois SesquiCentennial.  The first performance is scheduled at Northwestern U. on Feb 14th.
Completed

I am going ahead with Norm on our projected book tentatively titled "Songs for Men (and Stouthearted women")  We are making up a presentation in search of a publisher and it is in this connection I ask a favor of you.  I would like to include the purported speech in Congress titled "Change the name of Arkansas".  Studs had it but can't find it.  Do you have it?  If so, would you send me a copy which I can zerox [sic] and send back to you immediately.   We plan to include early English, restoration Civil War, World War I & II and contemporary bawdy songs as well as choice pieces of gusty prose like Mark Twains 1601, and the Arkansas piece with liberal quantities of un-bowlderized folk songs.  I have been working at Newberry and Brother, the harvest is ripe.
    I trust that Vance Randolph is still with us.  If you know an address for him, I would like to track down one of the three typwritten [sic] books of salty folklore that you mentioned had been purchased by as many librarys. [sic]  It would also be helpful if you could suggest an equitable arrangement, should we use any of his stuff --- and by the same token, what you would require, should you supply us with some gems.
    Ralph Newman is now Chairman of the Chicago Library Board of directors.  Not unrelated is the fact that I have been asked to do an article on the Library for Chicago Magazine.
   My singing duties took me to Cairo Ill
Completed

last week but I had to return the following day.  I'm scheduled to sing in Carbondale on January 18.  Should one of Vance Randolph's books turn up in the University of Mo. library,  I could take a jaunt there for a couple of days and visit you enroute.  I hope it can work out because I would very much like to see you and Gladys.

   The school continues to prosper but we are faced with the necessity of moving.  We are about to mount a drive to build a home for the school.  Hold your hat, -- if we succeed it will be called "Carl Sandburg House"   Well -- he did quite a bit for folk music and folksay and besides, his name will draw dough.
    Again, draw deep from your well of charity and  forgive me for not singing last April.

With deep affection and high regard
Win
Completed
postcard IMAGE:   musicians in medieval clothing under stone arches
Completed

postcard  postmark  GUANAJUATO GTO   7 ENE 70 - 8
Mexico, Jan 5, 70
Dear Folk:

   Here you see the Guanajato branch of the Old Town School of Folk Music giving a concert in a congenial sewer.   I met a Presbyterian missionary in Oaxaca and gave him one of your Xmas tracts.  No effect!  Saw old Russ Ames - unproductive as ever.  Betty and I wish you the Best  With Love, Win.

Jack and Gladys Conroy
701 Fisk ave.
Moberly Mo.  65270
Completed

April 11, '70
Dear Jack

   By the puny penis of a Peruvian prince, I am sorry.  I won't be at Rackensack this year as we are presenting Malvina Reynolds in concert on April 17, -- next Friday.  There will be a good number of people from the school present, but none that you know well.  Dawn is recovering from a ruptured disc and, as you know, Mountain View in the spring is no place to go with a sore back, even with one of your dildoes.
   Next year I may participate in the centennial celebration of Montgomery Ward.  I still recall the boyhood thrills I experienced when viewing the lady's underwear ads.
   On the 25th of April we're having an autographing bash for Studs' new book "Hard Times" -- unless the truck strike intervenes.  How dare anyone celebrate "Hard Times" without the presence of Jack Conroy.
   Betty sends her very best to you and Gladys et al. as do I.  she has recently been promoted to Vice President of her company.
   Give my best too to Jimmy Driftwood, Cleta, Glen Ohrlin and any and all kindred spirits you meet.

With Warm Regards
Win
Completed

letterhead  Win Stracke  1936 N. Clark St.  Chicago, Illinois  60614
All Saints Day '71
Dear Jack

    Methought 'twould be amiss were I not to add to your already bulging file of Strackiana.
    Peter Seeger is going to adjust my "clout city" piece to "Fun City" and perform it at Carnegie Hall thus adding my name to the illustrious like Bach Beethoven Brahms and other bums whos [sic] works have been performed there.
    I was pleased to know you liked the double underlined:  anonymous piece I included in my last missive.
    I hope you are all well.

Love to all
Win
Completed

letterhead  Win Stracke  1936 N. Clark St.  Chicago, Illinois  60614
July 3, '71
Dear Jack

   Many moons have passed since smoke signals have gone up between us but my thoughts toward blood brother Big Bear Conroy remain constant and warm.
   So saying I have big favor to ask.  you remember doggerel verse I dedicated to  you titled "Crime doesn't pay" ?  I am getting together all the poetry (?) and songs I have composed through the years and I can find no copy of said song.  If you will send me your copy I will have it zeroxed [sic] and return it post haste.  I plan to revise it some and when I have so done, I will send you original of revised version to swell your already voluminous collection of memorabilia.
   Norm Luboff and my book of ribald song verse and prose (also graphiti) has been accepted by Playboy Press for publication in the fall of 1972.  The contract is not signed as yet but I'm expecting no difficulty.  I should like to confer with you on this project some time in the next six months - for a fee of course.
   Betty and I are together again and we often speak of you and Gladys.
Completed

My daughter Jane is now an editorial supervisor at Encyclopedia Brittanica with thirty researchers under her -- hence "my daughter the executive".  My older daughter Barbara is expecting her first child on or around August 22nd and I will then join the ranks of grandfathers.
    Life in Chicago continues to be most exciting.  Wish you were here.  Had dinner with Studs and Ida last Saturday evening.  Studs has started a new book based on people and their jobs.  He has discovered a marvelous man named Mayhew (friend of Dickens) who was doing the same type of thing Studs is doing in London early in the nineteenth century.  You probably know of him if I know you.
    I hope this finds you hard at work in the midst of writing your memoirs.
    At the present time my plan is to get away from Chicago winters and spend three moths each year in Mexico.  I don't know if you heard but last October I was struck by an Avis Rent-a-Car (They're Number two -- the [sic] hit harder) while talking to a friend across the street from my apartment.  My skull was fractured and my knee torn apart.  I spent a month in hospital and was in cast with crutches for another two crossed  out:  moths months.   But I'm feeling fine again and except for a limp I'm ready for bear.
Completed

I'm planning a book on Eugene Field after the Ribald book is ready.  In your occasiona [sic] visits to Columbia, you might see if they have any Quantity of his correspondence.  If so, it would be a nice justification to visit you in Moberly.
   Give my very warmest regards to Gladys, Margaret et al.

And to you good friend,
Love
Win
Completed

Oct 31 '71  To Jack and Gladys with Love   Win
underlined:  Choosing an Architect  Chicago '71 by Win Strache.   Tune:  Bury me not on the Prairie or, I've got no use for the women
1.  A business man sits in his office
With the young architect of his choice.
He glares at the sketches 
And practically retches
But then to his thoughts he gives voice:
2.  "First, understand why you were chosen
I hear you've no talent at all;
Tho'  your work's not respected
you seem well connected
With the Powers down at City Hall."
3.  "Don't build me an elegant structure.
Make it sort of ugly and square.
If artists abhor it
Just try to ignore it
I want to make big profits there".
4.  "Don't use any ornamentation,
Let's get that straight right from the start,
'cause sure as perdition some future commission 
Will have it adjudged as great art."
5.  "Provide for the maximum floor space, 
Let the minimum monies be spent;
I'll have no compunction
If form follows function'
As long as that function is rent."
6.  When the time comes that we must destroy it
Let it not be occasioned by grief; 
Let there be no crying 
or Sobbing or Sighing,
Unless it's a sigh of relief."        
© by Win Strache  1971
Completed
postcard - IMAGE:  sea in background, high rise building in background, conical grass huts in front.
Completed

postcard  244.--Vista del Hotel Camino Real Hotel Camino Real view Puerto Vallarta, Jal.  Mexico
postmark  CORREOS PUERTO VALLARTA, JAL    29 DEC 1971  10:00
Dec 28 '71
Dear Jack and Gladys

  If temperature is any criterion, Betty and I are half way to Hell and my, but it's sweet.  The daily press tells us that the righteous up north are having a mild winter.  Never fear - the Devil's Justice will prevail.  I'm planning on staying down here for three months.  Saw Slim Brundage in Guadaljara.  Hope you all have a Good New Year   Win


Brother Jack and Gladys Conroy
701 Fisk ave.
Mobrely Missouri  65270  U.S.A.
Completed

824 West Rollins
Moberly, Missouri
March 14, 1967
Dear Mr. Conroy,

     Since we have met, I saw no need of making this a formal letter.  You told me when you brought the crutches back to our rental place, if I would write you, you would answer, so that I might add your letter to my collection of letters from prominent people.
     I would be proud to receive one from you, and especially since you are back in our home town.
     May you have many enjoyable days here in Moberly.
     Thank you very much.

Sincerely,
Mrs. Tom Stroud
Completed

[stamped letterhead]]  824 West Rollins    Moberly, Missouri  65270  Phone:  Area Code 816 263-1216
Dear Mr. Conroy:

    I always enjoy reading about whatevr you are doing and always say that Moberly should be proud to have you in our midst.
    My husband and I are very interested in the Bicentennial activities and are on the Heritage Committee.  We love history and believe it is so important for today and tomorrow.
    I have always had a deep respect for persons who are gifted and who have developed their talents for the enjoyment of others.  One of my hobbies is writing to these persons  telling them how much I appreciate what they do, in whatever field their talents are channeled.  A few years ago, you wrote me a very nice letter which I  have in my book.
Completed

I guess because of this hobby, I have been appointed a committee of one to contact all well-known persons in or from our area to ask them if they would write a resumé (short or long)  regarding their lives in our community and what they have done if they have left.  These letters will be put in a portfolio and placed with all the other relevant materials collected so that future generations will know about and have a deeper appreciation of the kind of place Moberly and Randolph County was and who our famous people were.
    We have several months for our projects.  We will all appreciate whatever you can do.  I would also appreciate a snapshot if you have one available.
    Thank you very much.

Sincerely, (Mrs. Tom) Anna Margaret Stroud
Completed

postcard  postmark  MOBERLY MO 65270  FEB 18  PM  1976
Mr. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, Missouri
Completed

824 W. Rollins
Moberly, Missouri
February 17, 1976
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   There is still plenty of time on my project, but I just wanted to be sure I would get the resume of your work.
    Thank you.

Anna Margaret Stroud
Many people I contacted, when they answered, inquired if I had contacted you.
Completed

824 West Rollins
Moberly, Missouri
August  25, 1976
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    My file of resumes of well-known persons in/ from Moberly has been turned over to the Executive Committee of the Bicentennial Museum Committee.
    One of the members requested I write you again and ask for a resume of your work and connection with Moberly.  This, when compiled, will be on display at the grand opening.  We are proud of you and need this.
    Thank you very much -

Anna Margaret Stroud
Completed

824 West Rollins
Moberly, Missouri
October 15, 1976
Dear Mr. Conroy,

     Please accept my sincere thanks for the beautiful resumé you sent me.  It was worth waiting on.
     It is so beautiful, and it nearly brought tears to my eyes.  What a wonderful talent you possess!
     The "Who's Who" article was extra special.
     I gave them to one of the Committee to be place in Book III at the Museum.  These books are permanent additions and are not for sale.  They house the resumés I have collected and are entitled "Moberly People of Fame".  If you go to the Museum, you will know what to look for.
     Thank you again and the best to  you always.

Anna Margaret Stroud
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Stroud, Anne Margaret
824 W. Rollins
Moberly, Missouri  65270
May 16, 1978
Dear Mr. Conroy:

   I did appreciate the resumé material you sent for the museum.  It is in the "Moberly People of Fame" books.
   There is another favor I am asking - we have a room now designated as our "library" and are getting many books.  I would be so grateful and all who work with the museum would, if we had an autographed copy of one of your books to place there.  If you would care to do this, you may call me at 263-1216, and I will be happy to pick it up.
    Thank you for any consideration.

Sincerely,
Anne Margaret Stroud
Completed

Dear Jack & Gladys -

   You all have been on my mind most persistently so I decided it might be my ESP at work again and I would just write and inquire about everyone.  Hope this finds you all well and happy - please write when you can and put my mind at rest.
    I have been in bed for a couple of weeks - been taking my Medicine - I guess you know that I am on Chemotherapy - Cytoxan is the drug I take and it makes me sick.  The side-effects are most undesirable, the underlined: most worst thing is what it does to my blood.  The drug works with the white cells and in the process it destroys them.  So, after a while, I have no defense against any disease germs
Completed

2
and a cold could become pneumonia and fatal.  The red cells are destroyed too, and when the anemia & white cell count reach a certain level, then I stop the drug - build my blood up again and then start over again.

     Mother went home a couple of days ago, she came up for a week and stayed until I felt better.  She was here when James Eugene came up - I got a birthday cake for her & she celebrated early.  She really was happy to see him.  He looks fine - hasn't changed at all.  Perhaps a underlined"  little more mature, I guess Jackie was in the area, for a wedding I believe Jim said, but he didn't contact us.  We hoped they'd call & come over the weekend I had Mom's cake, No luck.
Completed

5
the money.

   COUNTESS A STAROTH

[witchcraft - Magic - Curses - Charms - Spells]

    P.O. Box 1413 - Oakwood Station
    Gretna, La.   70053

In case you would also care to consult her, I have included her address.   Now, if you have a need for Cleopratra's [sic] Love Incense - I will be glad to forward the directions to you.  I shall never be able to find "Olibanum Tears", so shall have to do without this exotic incense.  I don't know what "Patchouly" leaves are either.

    I used the name not my own when I wrote.  To such things am I reduced when I am laid up and bored to death.  All of TV is reruns, even the talk shows are really lousy.
Completed

6.
I am taking Vitamin E, C, dessicated liver, lecithin, rose hips and still feel rotten, but they do help.  I take a magazine called underlined: Prevention that really tells double underlined:  all about food additives & chemicals in our food.  Some of the things they tell about really turn my stomach.   Ice cream is really a horrible mixture of gook, even terribly dangerous stuff produces that creamy goodness.  I can't eat it any more.   I haven't been able to eat hot dogs for 2 years. since I found out whats in them.  I really loved chili dogs, too!   I bought one but I couldn't even bite it.  Oh well, my pleasures diminish daily.

    Please excuse this ramble - when you can - write - the mailman's visit is a large event.

The best to you all -
Eve.
Completed

in pencil in top margin   [1969]
Dear Jack & Gladys -

    Hi - you all have been on  my mind lately, so decided to write & say hello - Hope everything is O.K. with everyone - I am still recuperating from my last surgery a month or so ago - feel pretty good but still not back to par yet.  Picked up a virus - was in bed for several days with that - but thats gone now.
    Arnold continues to work 7 days a week - all he does is work, eat & sleep.  He is getting on in years (who isn't?) he will be 71 or 72 in December.  "Retire" is a dirty word to him.  I think the tax situation will force him out of business as he can't make enough to stay even.
    Mother seems to be all right, but Ransom has taken to his bed & refuses to budge.   Helen is staying with them since Mother is not to be left alone & certainly can't carry trays upstairs to R.
Completed

2.

   I never hear from the boys - perhaps because I don't write to them.  I just hate to write letters so I guess I can't blame anyone else.  I have lost everyone's address.  I'd write to Jean but don't know where.
   I am enclosing a clipping which may be of interest.  I don't know if you receive any Chicago papers & have seen this or not.
   Well, say hello to everyone & if the boys have time ask them to write - also Jean - or will  you send me their address?  I owe Jean a letter -
    Will close so Arnold can mail this when he goes to the store -

Love to all
Eve Strufe
Completed

in pencil in top margin   [1972]
Dear Gladys & Jack -

     Just a line to say hello and to thank you both for a wonderful visit.  I can't tell you how much we enjoyed seeing all of you after such a long time.  And Gladys, I can still taste your fried chicken & baked ham.  Delicious!
    I hope you can read this - I broke my glasses - shattered into a million pieces - and I can barely see what I am writing in these driving glasses, in fact its all a sort of blur.
    Anyway, again thanks & and Mother and I send our love to you all.  We enjoyed the day with Jean so much and appreciate her coming from Columbia and
Completed

taking us on the grand tour.

   Hope you all will find time to write once in a while.

Sincerely,
Eve & Helen K.
Completed

Aug. 30th 1939
Riverton, Ky.
Jack Conroy, Esq., 
The New Anvil,
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Jack Conroy:

   If you can lift a paragraph or two from this story without injury to the story, you have my permission to do so.   It is entirely too long.  It is a story but few magazines would dare publish and several writers would not care to write it.
    You are a Southerner, so am I.  We know that in the South, White men have had woods colts by Colored women; Whereas, on the other side, if a black man assaults a white woman - you know what happens.  it is my belief that the white should remain white and the black remain black.  If I were a Negro, I wouldn't want a drop of white blood in me.  We (the Whites) have certainly been unfair to the Negro women don't you think?
    My story is based on facts.  You can believe it or not - but it is.  The women lived in the rock cliff as I wrote in the story.  I didn't know whether to make a story or a short novelette
Completed

2
out of this material.  I wrote the story last year in Edinburgh, Scotland.   A minister read the story and gave me a title for it.  He liked the story.

   I didn't expect pay for this story.  I didn't send it expecting money.  I saw your new magazine advertised in underlined:  Poetry:  A Magazine of Verse; therefore, I sent you this story that has been turned down by a number of magazines in this Country - all with comments about it -
   And I sent you this story (though it may be a sorry story - I don't know -) as an appreciation for a copy of your underlined: Disinherited (Malcolm Cowley sent me long ago) which is one of the finest books I've ever read in my life.  It is truly a great book.  My brother James and  I talk about it still.
    I've never made much money from my stories and less from my books and all I have made I've sunk it on my farms Which certainly hasn't been a paying proposition.  if it hadn't been for my few sales to Collier's and my many sales to Esquire I don't know what I would have done because money has been something for me to spend and not to have.
   Good luck to you.

Always,
Jesse Stuart
Completed

April  21st 1940
Riverton, Ky.
Jack Conroy, Esq.,
3569 Cottage Grove Ave., 
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Jack Conroy:

    Some of these times I'll go through all of my stories and see if I can find another underlined:  Sour Grapes.  I wrote this story in Scotland.  I thought first I'd make a novelette out of it.  There was a preacher living near.  He spoke of the spiritual resurrection - not the physical resurrection as our good Baptist preach here.  He discussed this story with me.  He liked it after I'd written it.  I suppose I sent that story 25 trips, while in the West, I heard many comments on this story - believe it or not.  I was surprised to hear them for I didn't know underlined:  The New Anvil had much circulation.
    Jack do you know anything about underlined:  Decade a magazine that uses short stories that is published
Completed

2
in Chicago.  I've got a letter from the editor asking for a story and he writes that he wrote me a year ago and I'd never answered.

   You did better on your tour than I did.  To tell you the truth, I just about broke even but I did get a glimpse of America.  That's something I'd longed to see.  One of the most interesting places for me was Flat River, Mo. - near the Ozarks.  I found my own people here.  I met a friend of yours - Fitzgerald.  Do you remember him?
   Say where is old Don West now?  I'd like to hear from him.  Where does he live?  Can you give me his address?  If you can, send it to me immediately.
   Water is getting in at our back door here in the Ohio River Valley.  I'm staying with my wife's people now.  Soon if it keeps rising, I'll be on my way out to my hill farm.  Good luck Jack and best wishes.

Sincerely,  Jesse Stuart.
P.S.  Hope my novel only sells half as well as Richard Wright's.  I've had a hell of a hard time this winter.
Completed

Riverton, Ky.
June 10th 1946
Dear Jack Conroy:  

    Sorry I'm just now answering your good letter with your review (and a review from The New Masses) of underlined:  Foretaste of Glory.   Some contrasts in the two reviews.  The New Masses reviewer intimated such didn't happen.  At least that's the way I interpreted it,  you intimated it did in your review and said so in your letter and I say you are right.   I know, I was there and saw it happen.
    See,  You and I are from (well, I am here still) practically the same County, you  have a deep feeling for it and will probably return someday, when you go to writing about the pawpaw patches down in the hollows and the cow trails among them I know what you mean.  And the persimmon groves upon the ridges - Both are possums' delight.  A persimmon or a pawpaw is the same to a possum as a good steak is to a man.
    When underlined:  Taps for Private Tussie came out,
Completed

2
my good old friend and fellow classmate, and fellow Cross-Country and long distance man of former days departed me.  Did you see  his review in Mountain Life and Work, official publication of Berea College?   Dan almost died when this book was published and it would have been appropriate for me to have sent him a long empty coffin, made like a guitar box, (big for shoulders and tapering at the feet - a real old time coffin and not one of these modern caskets with the bright handles)  since I would  have been the cause of his death.

   I wonder if you run into this sort of thing when The Disinherited was published?  If I were to list ten of the best books written by Americans of all times, this novel would be one -   Hell, the reaction around here to underlined:  Foretaste of Glory has been unfavorable -  but I 'm surprised at Dan's being so reactionary (but don't forget he preaches)   About my books, I'd never have thought it, I hope, the for books that he has to be published are all masterpieces.  And I mean this!  The South needs more
Completed

3.
Writers and, naturally, good men.

   I'm sorry that I didn't get to see you when I was at Great Lakes.  When I come to Chicago unless I'm just passing through I'd like to meet you - sit down for a good talk, smoke, food -- drink -- all best wishes ---

Sincerely,
Jesse Stuart
P.S.  After West reviewed underlined:  Taps I wrote him a funny letter, Hell, he never answered it!  I bragged on the review - told him I needed it - But West doesn't have much humor.  He doesn't laugh enough.  He thinks too much about underlined:  the here and especially the [[underlined:  hereafter.}  He used to spend most of his time preparing on underlined:  the here for [underlined:  the hereafter.]]
Completed

   Next news:  Please relay to Pistol Gunn underlined:  et al:  We have a new son, born 2 Oct 1971, reached us on 18 Oct 1971.  Both his parents black, young.  That's all we know.  He is still light, but our Black friends tell us he will darken.  His eyes are grey-blue, but

should shade into Brown.  Name:  Joshua Kevin Alexander Suggs.

him the merger (acquisition?) news.

    Hope Moberly is sliding into Autumn with Grace.  You sound able as ever.  Must be avoiding The Demon Rum as per instructions.  We hope all is well with Giggly Gladys and the grandson.

15 Apr 74
Dear Jack -

  Excuse this brief note after such a long time.  I am harried and hurried, but have just resolved something that has been at the back of my mind and tho't I'd bring you up to date.
  Soon after you wrote me I read Dan Levin's review of underlined:  The Disinherited and wrote a  2½  page letter correcting misstatements and wrongheadedness - a damn fine letter.  I waited and
Completed

waited but it never appeared.  School and personal emergencies crowded it out for awhile, but I've just got off the phone to the Book Editor of underlined:  The Nation who claims never to have received it -- so I'll send it now - again!
More later
Siempre
Chris

Dear Jack -

  I'm going over the copies of Rebel Poet you sent me, I can say that the stuff in them is more representative of the turbulent pre-Rooseveltian thirties than any publication I know.  I should like to have them all and have asked my book dealer to advertise for them.  If I should get any duplicates and you need them, will be glad to let you have them.
  We are now in the throes of moving again - the 10th time in 6 yrs. - and I hope that my books, if not my bones will get a deserved rest.

Best regards and thanks.
Marvin

Dear Jack & Gladys!

      This stationary is several days old.  We are now in San Antonio Texs these past two days.  Have been several interesting places in New Mexico, Texas & Mexico.  We are driving - & have been since May 27th.
      Before now, we were words covered by paper fold Padre Island.  This has been a great trip.  But we are heading for home now.  That is tomorrow - may be!!
      I forgot my address book so could not send card but suddenly thought perhaps a letter
Completed

without a full address would reach you.

    Hope all is well with you & you have leak stopped in basement -  If you get this -  Let us hear from you -

in pencil at top of page  H. Sullivan  [1948]
2
I meant to write to you before but I couldn't get your address.  I still think the printer may have made a mistake on your beautiful letter-head.  There's no 69 anywhere!  How come? I am now a turret expediter at the Emerson Electric Co.  We make turrets for Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers.  Specifically I expedite for the Lower Sperry or ball turret, and supervise three small, despondent 4F expediters.  None of them, however, will say "yessir" to me.  I'm on the night shift.  We have about 2000 women and 400 men so some of the guys (though not me, since Mary may read this) are fond of calling themselves sexpediters.
This war has certainly scattered all of us hell, west, and crashed.  You, alone, hold the fort in Chcago.  Vic, I hear, is in North Africa on "shore duty" - which probably means the brig.  I want to write to him if I can ever sit down to do it.
Completed

3
I'd like to get off a few tender lines to Bird and Nelson, too.  Especially Bird, basking on an exotic South Sea island while here I am working away in a factory to make things safe for him and his children.  Of course I get sixty bucks a week and all the beer I can drink but that doesn't make my sacrifice any easier.
I guess I won't start getting kicked around until after March 1.  I have a 2B classification until then, when I will try to get into the Merchant Marine.
Come down as soon as you can, Jack.  My hours make it mandatory for me to start my social life at about 6 A.M. - I work from 8:30 P.M. to  6 A.M. - but try to get down on a weekend.  If not, we'll halt turret production for a beloved friend.  Best regards from Mary and my own Johnnie Walker.  Hello to Gladys and all.
Love,
Harold Sullivan
Completed

Jan 12 1968
Dear Jack & Gladys -

   Want to thank you for a most pleasant visit.  Hope you will be coming up this way soon.   Sorry we didn't get to see Margaret Jean again before we left.   Duke hasn't been feeling too well since we got back.  Caught cold & only now getting rid of it.  The weather here mostly has been pretty awful. & just now really pretty bad - 
   We got back with just minutes to spare to pick up the dog. & the next day he was sick enough to die.  Seems something is going around among dogs very much like flu with people.  Muchacho doesn't know he is a dog & always has a bed time in a kennel.
   Jack, I want to thank you again for the copy of Anyplace But Here.  I have been reading it every chance I get.  don' want this to sound like a conversation between Joey Bishop & one of his guests though.  If you ever watch him you know what I mean.  If you haven't I'll explain when we see you.
   Duke is busy working on one of his statistical fantasies & has been for some evenings now.  I do not understand any part of it but it is always a beautiful piece of
Completed

design when he gets finished.  But he does send his best regards to you both.  He really enjoyed his visit with you.

    Glady [sic] I hope you are feeling good by this time.  Take care of your self.  We hope to see you soon
    Hello to Margaret Jean & great little boy --

Love
Mary
Completed

Thurs. 4/17/69
Dear Jack -

   With the mix-up, hang-up about your check & tickets -- Wot happened to your schedule?!!
    Do hope by this time you have been found & you are settled & ready for your talk.   We have been worried.  Know you & friend missed each other at airport.  But Gladys K. said if didn't call back could assume all was well.
    Hope your T.V. appearances & talk are great.
    See  you Sunday airport here.  If we have mix up at gate we will have you paged.

Love,   Mary
Duke at work & feeling better this morning but sends his best regards!

Completed

Sept.  2 '69
Hi Jack -

   Well, it has taken some days & phone calls but I finally have something to pass along to you.  I called the number you sent without results.  So looked the place up in the 'phone book.  They listed four places.  N. side S. side W. side & Illinois.  Called all from time to time.  Nothing.  Today I got the S. side number only to learn that it is an answering service & they no longer answer for Vulcan.
   Then I called the Better Business Bureau.  They said Vulcan is no more.  However, I told them your story.  Said they would try to help you but you must write them or call them yourself.  Their ad is  901 Washington (63101) 'phone numbers are 241-3100  This number looks up companies for you.   241-9676 is for grievances.  (If you decide to call this would be best bet.  The                  241-9676.
   You can also call or write CONSUMER  -Consumer Fraud  705 Olive  Suite 1323  St Louis, MO  63101   'phone No.  Ch. 1-2211
Completed

Jack, if you write I think I would write to each place & perhaps by the time you get here they will have some news for you.  Or maybe, even before you get here.
  (I will, of course, pick you up at airport & return you.  but the airport is now a complete mess.   Say it will be so for two years.  So let me know flight number, time of arrival & airline & I will pick you up at airport door. & will have to deposit you at same.  The parking lot is now a mile & a half from airport entrance & much construction to get through.  So, this is way they suggest you pick up & return people involved in airline transportation.  I just took Michael & Sue out there Saturday morning 6:30 in morning & deposited them at T.W.A. entrance.  When they return next week they will call me while waiting on their baggage & I will go out & pick them up.
    We will be happy to see you again.  Wish Gladys could come along.  Say hello to her & we will see you soon.
    Hope you can get something out of the Vulcan outfit --

Love   Mary
Duke sends his best to you & Gladys.   Looking forward to your visit.
Completed

Oct. 28 '69
Dear Jack -

   Hope your trip was O.K.   Would have sent your shirt sooner but Muchacho died the 20th.  The Monday afternoon after you left.
   So, last week was a very sad, can't do anything week.  Duke was heart sick & still is - but he knows now he will survive.
   We bought a puppy, 9 wks old.  Collie - Tri-color - & looks very like Muchacho - so this week end Duke was kept busy taking him in & out - We are house breaking him - that's a full time job - Really keeps you hopping - but it was good for Duke & he is feeling better now.
    Trust you found your family well when you got back.  Probably good to be home again.
    Will go to post office soon as puppy goes to sleep.
    Hello to Gladys & Jerry

Love,  Mary
Completed

Wenes.  May 6 '70
Hi Jack & Gladys -

   Much has happened to us since last we talked.  Duke lost his job Dec 31
   A man ran into the rear of my car & practically demolished it.  We put our house up for sale & sold it in four days.  So, now we are wandering nomads.  Stayed at my sister's for a week after we  had to leave our house.  Sold most of our furniture -
   To be brief - We got our car back April 17th (accident happened Feb 26th)  Moved out April 18th.  New people wanted in that day.  We are now at SURF APT. MOTEL
Completed

3420 Gulf Blvd. Belleair Beach, Florida.  We pulled in last Thurs evening - & will stay another week - Really nice here.  Small apt. right on the beach - Miles of beautiful beach  five minutes from Clearwater ½ hr from St. Petersburg.  Will look for something to rent by the month, maybe, in St. Petersburg.  Have dog with us - & Florida places are hard to get with dog.  We drove to Sarasota Monday   Lovely there.  Come visit us if we get settled somewhere.  At least write a few lines, right away while we have an address  Will probably check out week from tomorrow morning - check out time 11 in morning -- Duke on beach practically always, but sends his best to you both -
Love Mary
Completed

postcard  Just a line  File:Woman in ruffled dress hanging clothes on clothesline
9/17/70
Dear Jack & Gladys - Hi!   We have both been very busy this past month making a garden spot.  So call, write, or come see us & stay a while.  We can sleep twelve.  A block from the ocean & a fishing jetty - & a tavern you can see the ocean from the house.  What more could you ask for?!!  The weather is good.  Let's hear from you.  Love Mary

April 22  '71
Dear Jack -

    Always good to hear from you.  Wish you would think of us more often.   We are very sorry to learn of your hospital stay, however.  Why don't you and Gladys come down here & get well?!  I will see to it that you do not get any sugar - or booze.  The Bushman's call from time to time & they are supposed to be here shortly after Johnny gets finished his school work.  About June 18th or so.  They are going to Iowa to see Fritz too.  Don't know which they will do first.  Here or Iowa.  But they have said they would for sure be here & we are to have some company sometime in August for several days.  Michael will be down in August maybe
   So, you & Gladys should be able to get away for a while.  We have plenty of room & the weather is great.
Completed

I think I told you before we are only half a block from the ocean   The view is good & while we are not isolated, we do not have neighbors too close.  Duke spends as much time as he can outdoors & we often spend the entire day on the beach.   We aren't making any money, but we are enjoying ourselves.  Very pleasant life this.

   Haven't heard from Finch since his move to Calif.  My sister & her husband were here last month   Seemed to enjoy themselves.  This is Earth Week you know.  Suppose to use both sides of paper & we buy our beer in bottles.  Duke sees to it that none of it stands around & causes clutter.  Also, immediately return the empties for refills.  Wears few clothes that need to be washed.  Mostly goes about in small pair of swim trunks.  Feels he is doing his part toward pollution, etc.
   As for 'Dirty Dick' & hero Calley
Completed

I couldn't repeat his views - we would probably be tarred & feathered with our own dear dog.  Suppose he would like someone to talk with from time to time.
    Most here are the Hero Calley type.  Except for that - All goes well with us.
   We both hope you & Gladys stay well & Margaret Jean.  Bring her along & her husband.
  Meanwhile -- Take care & let us hear from you.  Duke sends regards to you both --

Love   Mary
Completed

   One is for a friend of ours.  you have met her.  We took her to
Completed

a couple of the parties on Franklin, when you were in town.  Long time ago, you couldn't remember her.  She rented a room from us in that first house we bought.  That's thirty five years ago.

    One is for Michael our son, he is an assistant circuit attorney for the city of St. Louis, several years now.  He will be especially pleased.
    & of course, one is for Harold.  He is still working & feeling pretty well for 68
    The St. Louis Post Sunday Magazine section ran a very nice article about you which Polly sent to us.  Guess Wharton sent one to you.
    Do I need to say we want all three copies autographed.
    Stay well Jack!   Take care

Love,  Mary
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sullivan, Mary Ellen
1-16-83
Midwest Distributors
P.O. Box 4642
Kansas City, Mo.  64109
Dear Sirs:

      Check enclosed for 20.10 for three copies of The Disinherited  5.95 each plus .75 for postage.  Jack Conroy is a very good friend of ours.  He just sent this information said he would be there the 26th of Feb. & that he would autograph each copy.  So, please show him this

Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sullivan, Mary  [1983]
greeting card  How dear to my heart are the scenes of my childhood, When fond recollection presents them to view.   SAMUEL WOODWORTH
Wishing you a good old-fashioned Christmas and a very happy New Year.
Dearest Jack - Hi!  Hope this is not too bad time of year for you & I do hope some one is there with you now.

   Wish you could come down.  Our weather has been delightful.  Don't think weather your way has been much to talk about.
   Duke is still working.  But end of this month will be end of job.  He is quite despondent about it all.  Wonders what he will do.  His general health is O.K. but somewhat on frail side.  Can't do what he used to do.  But, that is the same cry from all of us.  I think we should be thankful to be alive & well.
   Hope you are feeling O.K. Jack - Stay well.   Take care.   Much love,  Mary & Duke
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sullivan, Mary
6/13/84
Dear Jack - Hi!

   We received a clipping from a St. Louis paper  Probably the Post about Jack Conroy Day in Moberly.  It sounded like a very good turn out for you.  We are happy for you.
    Duke wanted to be there, but I didn't want to drive so far & Kansas City was as close as we could get him by plane.  He didn't know how he could get the rest of the way.  The girls at Eastern said Moberly was 70 miles at least.  
    As it turned out, I was in hospital with chest pains.  I have angina.
Completed

Otherwise, we are both fine here.  Hard for Duke to get around when I'm not here.  He never cared to drive.
   Real handicap when you live in a place without public transportation.
   It is a quite nice article about you.  With a really good picture.
   You seem full of vim & vigor.  Hope you are feeling well.
   We still stay in touch with the Bushmans via phone & mail & get an occasional letter from Russell Finch.
    Have you really grown a beard?  I am looking forward to Conroy's collected stories & the autobiography.  So, Take care

Love, Mary Ellen
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Sullivan, Mary Ellen   Ft. Pierce, Fl
6/12/85
Dear Jack,  I hope this reaches you, somehow, Jack & I hope you are better.

    I have sad news.  Harold died June 1.  He, I & Michael was sitting on the side of the bed.  He was here at home.  Michael was holding him in his arms & he just died.
    We learned Feb 4 he had cancer of the lung & lymph nodes around windpipe.  He had 36 radiation treatments.  Up & around.  Not a lot of energy, but up & around.  My life is not much without him.  I am going to St. Louis.  Stay with Polly for a few weeks.  
    Last year Midwest distributors sent me a list so I sent for Writers in Revolt, The Anvil Anthology & Meridel Le Sueur's Harvest & Song for My Time.   Harold he read each twice.  I do hope this reaches you, Jack & I do hope you are on the mend.

Love,  Mary Ellen
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Mary Ellen
7/30/85
Dear Jack,

    Glad you are recovering from your foot surgery. & I hope, by this date, you are also recovering from your eye operation.  Harold had a cataract removed & the implant last August.  Very successful.
  I left for St. Louis June 20h.  Returned just two weeks ago.  Had my little grandson here for past ten days.  He is three years old & a real live wire.  Kept me busy.
  Now I am alone again & am feeling that living without Harold is not worth much.  We traveled a long road together.  Some of it pretty rough, but we
Completed

always got through it together.  I know it was the same with you & Gladys.  I suppose God knows best.  He knows which one to take first.  Gladys couldn't have survived without you.  I feel that is one good thing.  Harold never learned to drive & he didn't bother with the bills, etc.  At least I can get in the car & take off when it gets too bad for me here.  & I am used to the paperwork involving medicine & other insurance.  So, I am able to get things taken care of that way.  He wouldn't have been able to do it all.

   But I miss him very much.  Sometimes, I feel I can't handle it.
   I don't mean to get morbid.  You've had enough
Completed

yourself -

   So, lets stay in touch on lighter things.
   I would like an autographed copy of your new book:  The Weed King & Other Stories
   If you [sic] book company or store will let me know I will send check.
   I do hope, Jack, that this finds you really on the mend.
   Take care,    Love, Mary Ellen
Completed

in pencil in top margin   Mary Ellen
Sept 16 '85
Dear Jack,

    Always so good to hear from you.  See you are back to your expert typing.  Wish I could say same about my handwriting.
    I'm sorry about your foot, Jack.  But, glad you can do something about it.  Know you are pleased with Chicago Tribune review of something had been in St. Louis Post I think some one would have clipped it out & sent it here.  Wish I could go to your autographing party in Oct.  Hope it is underlined: not your last hurrah.
   I just dropped Mr. Whitehead a note telling him I would send him a check for book, plus postage, either before or after he mails it.
Completed

I am still struggling to live without my Duke & am trying to stay here in my house.  It is not easy.  But, I am doing better.  I bought myself a little pup.  He will be six months old next week & he barks.  I have a dog, six years, but she doesn't bark & I have been scared here at night alone.   Somehow, now it is better.
    Have a good trip to Columbia.  I'll let you know when I get my book.
    Stay well, Jack     Take care.     Love    Mary Ellen

I save your letters, Jack.  Always have.
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Mary Ellen
10/11/85
Dear Jack,

    I received your book on the 25th of September.  I am enjoying it very much.  Do hope it is not your 'last hurrah.'   I can see why it received such a good review in the Chicago Trib.  Hope it is selling well.
    Along with my book was, also, a book for Baumburger (I think I remember that right) & in that book was an address on a scrap of paper.  Looked like it may have been from your typewriter & a check!   Made out to you from Baumburger.  I immediately rewrapped that book & its contents, enclosed my check for my book, plus postage & took it to post office
Completed

I mailed it back to Mid West, first class, with a note.  The next day or so I received a brief note from Fred Whitehead.  He had apparently received a letter from you saying I had not yet received my book.  So, I, at once, dashed off a note to him, about my check, my book, & the other book, etc.  His note is dated Sept. 25th.  Have heard nothing more from him so, guess it is all straightened out.  I just remember.  That name was Baumgarten, Arthur.  double  underlined:  I think.
  I didn't write you you had said you would be going to Columbia in early Oct.
Completed

Do wish all goes well with the new foot.  Awfully sorry there was a need for it.  Wish I could go to your party at City Hall -
   We have been lucky with the hurricanes so far.  Isobel just passed us by.  I get so unhinged about these storms since I am alone.  Just when I feel I am learning to live here alone, along comes a storm or hurricane, threat, that is & I fall apart.   Don't know if you know it.  But, our house is just west of AIA & the ocean is east of AIA.  you can see the ocean from our house & the inlet & a fishing jetty.  All very nice.  Really
Completed

scary though with 8 to 12 foot waves & high winds.  We have had to get out only one time.  Back in 1979 Duke worked for two days tying things down & putting everything movable in garage.  I doubt I can get through another hurricane season here alone.  It starts June 1 to Nov 30th   The bad time is end of Aug & Sept.  I was so glad when Sept was gone.  Then a week into Oct & we get Isobel

   Jack I am really enjoying The Weed King & I do hope all goes well with you.   I may go to St. Louis middle of Nov.  Not sure now.

Take care,
Love,
Mary Ellen
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Mary Ellen
1/26/85
Dear Jack,

    Thank you for sending the page from Columbia Tribune.  Very nice.   It should be on the front page.  Should have made the front pages of the Chicago papers too.   you certainly have a fan in Wixson.  you are, apparently, his God.  Makes you feel very proud.
    I'm glad you spread the word about Zora Neale   There was a quite nice article about her in the local paper early this year.   Duke planned on sending it to you.  I don't know now what became of it.
    I have had company from St. Louis all of last week   My nephew & his wife & sister in law.  They were all good company & I was glad
Completed

to have them but I am quite tired this week.  I drove up to West Palm today to see Duke's cousin who is quite ill & in the hospital.  A long drive.  Tomorrow I'm to go to Okeechobee for the day & Thurs. Michael, Susan & two kids will be here.  I am very tired now.

    Glad your surgery has come off well.  It will be better later.
    Jack, I hope you do make that trip to Ohio this spring.  I agree with Wixon that your book is equal to "The Grapes of Wrath" & that was one great book.
    Do you see your grandsons?  Gladys' sister Agnes?
    Hope you have a happy Thanksgiving.
    Let me hear about you when you can -

Love, Mary Ellen
